awd_titl_txt: CPS: Medium: GOALI: An Architecture Approach to Heterogeneous Verfication of Cyber-Physical Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
NSF CPS Proposal: 1035800
ABSTRACT
The objective of this research is to develop new methods for verifying the safety of complex cyber-physical systems based on information derived from the wide variety of models and methods used throughout the design process.    The approach is based on a new formalism to represent the architecture of systems with cyber components, physical components, and interconnections between these domains.   Diverse engineering models of different aspects of the system will be associated through the cyber-physical architecture for the complete system.  Formal logic will be developed to express and reason about inter-model consistency and to infer system-level properties from information derived from the domain-specific models.  
The project?s intellectual merit lies in the creation of a comprehensive, unified framework for verifying properties of systems rich in both cyber and physical components.  The new formal logic will make it possible to integrate information from the wide range of engineering domains and technical expertise required to design complex systems.  This will lead to a principled, rigorous approach to system-level verification engineering for real-world cyber-physical systems.
The application of the new methodology to verify the safety of cooperative intersection collision avoidance systems will have immediate impact on emerging technologies for safer automobile systems.  A new interdisciplinary course in engineering and computer science on system-level design of cyber-physical systems will prepare a new cadre of graduates with the cross-cutting skills needed to develop safety-critical systems.  Innovative educational modules will also be developed to inspire pre-college students to pursue education and careers in engineering and computer science.

por.por_cntn:
This collaboration between researchers at Carnegie Mellon University and Toyota addresses the problem of ensuring the correctness and safety of cyber-physical system designs. With an increase in automated vehicles, internet-of-things, and use of software in critical infrastructure such as power plants and buildings, developing robust software to control such cyber-physical systems is becoming essential – the lives of individuals and the well-being of society in general is increasingly dependent on having correct and safe cyber-physical systems. In classical control design, software was not a large part of the system and so models of the physical system dominated. However, these days software is a critical component, allowing the development of more complex cyber-physical systems that can be developed for more critical and challenging systems. Such an increase in complexity and domains means that there are a proliferation of different models that engineers use to verify that a system is safe. Unfortunately, these models only verify sub-parts of the system and do not allow systemic properties to be shown. What is needed are logics and frameworks that can reason about multiple models, so that, for example, the assumptions made in one model are guaranteed by other models.  

In this project, we developed a new approach for representing the structure and semantics of complex cyber-physical systems at an architectural level so that verification can be performed at the system level using different models and methods. This is achieved by defining families of components and connections that represent system elements from the cyber and physical domains, as well as the interconnections between these domains. By managing the relationships between these models at the architectural level, common structural and semantic features between the models can be exposed and leveraged to guarantee consistency between the models. Formal representations and semantics make it possible to reason about the assumptions made in building the veri?cation models and the implications from the heterogeneous veri?cation activities. Increasingly rich fragments of logic make it possible to express and reason about system-level properties, ranging from simple logical constraints to full logics for hybrid systems.

A complete CPS architectural framework was developed to encompass the full range of components and modeling formalisms used to design and implement cyber-physical systems.  Concepts from software architecture, which represents all aspects of cyber components and systems, were extended to represent physical components and behaviors governed by laws of physical dynamics. Interfaces between cyber and physical components are represented at the architectural level. The concept of architectural views was introduced as the means of supporting the rich and varied set of formalisms and tools used to develop complex cyber-physical systems.  Through formal annotations, the CPS architectural framework provides a principled means for assuring that assumptions made within the contexts of heterogeneous models used to design various aspects of the system are fundamentally consistent.  Moreover, the annotations anchored in the CPS architecture make it possible to compose inferences from multiple heterogeneous analyses to verify properties at the system level, thereby achieving formal assurances of system-level correctness that have in the past been obtained only by informal and ad hoc engineering intuition, if at all.
